arises because the DGVM methodological setup requires a reference simulation including climate and
environmental changes but without any land use change such as deforestation, so DGVMs implicitly
include the sink capacity forests would have developed in
response to environmental changes on areas
that in reality have been cleared

While such data can strongly support monitoring
reporting and verification, estimates of forest carbon
fluxes directly from Earth Observation (EO) data vary considerably in both their magnitude and sign
(i.e. whether forests are a net source or sink of carbon).
by spatial resolution of the d
ata sets, the definition of “forest” and the inclusion
and methods used to determine degradation and growth in intact and secondary forests
A recent global study integrated ground
observations and remote sensing data to map forest
emissions and removals at a high
spatial resolution (30m spatial scale), although it only provides an average estimate of annual carbon
. The estimated net global forest carbon sink globally wa
Remote sensing products can help to attribute changes to anthropogenic activity or natural inter
. Products with higher spatial resolution make
it easier to determine forest and carbon dynamics in relatively small
Brazilian Amazon offset 9 to 14% of gross emissions due to deforestation
. Yet disturbances such as fire and repeated deforestation cycles due to shifting
cultivation over the period 1985 to 2017, were found to reduce the regrowth rates of secondary forests
n the climate region of regrowth
